concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm glad you're here today. Feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling really lonely since moving for grad school. It’s tough not having people around and I'm struggling to focus on my studies because of it.
Therapist: It sounds like you're dealing with a lot, and it's understandable to feel that way. What do you think might help you feel more connected in your new environment?

client: I guess finding some sort of community or group could help, but it's hard with everything still being limited due to the pandemic. Maybe trying to reach out to classmates online or joining virtual events, but it doesn’t feel the same.
Therapist: It's great that you're considering ways to reach out and connect, even if the options feel different. What might be the first small step you could take toward engaging with others online?

client: Maybe I could start by joining some online study groups or forums related to my program. That way, I can at least talk to people with similar interests and maybe even make some friends that way.
Therapist: That sounds like a thoughtful step forward, and I admire your willingness to try something new. How would it feel to take that first step towards joining an online study group or forum?
client: I think it would feel a bit intimidating at first, but also kind of exciting to meet people who are interested in the same things. It might help make this transition a bit easier, you know?

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel both intimidated and excited about new experiences. Based on what you said, one option could be to start with a small, manageable forum or group and gradually participate more as you feel comfortable. Would you like to set a goal for how often you'd like to participate each week to ease into this transition?
client: Yeah, setting a goal sounds like a good idea. Maybe starting with once or twice a week could work, just to see how it goes and then I can adjust based on how comfortable I feel.

You've set a thoughtful and achievable goal of participating in online study groups or forums once or twice a week. This is such a positive step towards building community and easing into your new environment. Recognizing that it's both intimidating and exciting shows great insight and courage. As you start this journey, remember to be kind to yourself and take things at your own pace. You've demonstrated a lot of strength by taking this step, and I'm confident that you'll find ways to connect and feel more at ease over time. If you find yourself needing any extra support or want to reflect on how it's going, feel free to reach out. You're doing great, and we're here to support you every step of the way.
Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement. I'll try to take it slow and see how it goes, but it's nice to know I can reach out if I need to.

concern: I have never been in an academic setting that challenged me so much. In undergrad I was always on top of my work and had enough time to enjoy myself, go to the gym, and even party. In my second year of my PhD program all I do is work and on the weekends I usually sleep or go out somewhere just to try to enjoy myself. Now that the semester has begun I lost my Sundays to a full day of class work. I am so lucky to do what I love, but I love it a lot less when I am being overworked. It does not help that my PI is an absolute workaholic. How do people not burn out working 6 days a week with such mentally involved tasks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind or anything you'd like to discuss today.
Hey, thanks for having me. Honestly, I've just been struggling with finding balance in my PhD program. It's been a lot to handle, and I'm starting to feel worn out.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the demands of your PhD program. Can you tell me more about what's been particularly challenging for you?
client: Yeah, it's just that the workload never seems to end. Finding time for myself is almost impossible, and it's like every aspect of my life is consumed by this.
That sounds really tough, and it's understandable to feel that way with such a heavy workload. In what ways do you imagine your life might be different if you were able to find more balance?
I guess I'd feel more energized and motivated. I'd probably enjoy my work more if I had time to just relax and do other things I love without feeling guilty or stressed.

It sounds like having more balance could really enhance your energy and enjoyment of your work. What are some of the activities you love doing that would help you recharge if you had more time for them?
Honestly, I miss just going to the gym or catching up on a good book. Even just hanging out with friends without constantly thinking about what I should be working on would be nice.

Those activities sound really fulfilling and could offer a great break from your PhD demands. It's understandable that you'd want to enjoy these moments without the weight of stress constantly on your mind. How do you feel about the possibility of integrating some of these activities into your routine, even in small ways?

I think it would make a big difference, but it's hard to see how to fit them in with everything else going on. It feels like even small breaks might take away from the time I need to keep up with my work.

It sounds like you're recognizing the value of taking breaks but are concerned about fitting them into your busy schedule. Based on what you've shared, one option could be to start by scheduling short, consistent breaks for activities like reading or a quick gym visit. Another option might be to set aside a specific time each week to connect with friends. How do these options sound to you for starting to find some balance?
They sound like good ideas in theory, but I'm worried I'll end up feeling guilty for taking even a small break. Sometimes I feel like I need permission to take time off without falling behind.

It's understandable to feel that way, and it's great that you're being so honest about your concerns. One idea might be to reframe these breaks as essential parts of maintaining your productivity and wellbeing, rather than taking away from your work. How do you feel about setting a small, specific goal, like one short gym session or a coffee with a friend per week, and reflecting on how it affects your stress and productivity?

I think setting a small goal like that might be a good start. I just need to remind myself that taking a bit of time away could actually help me stay productive in the long run. It’s just tough to shake the guilt sometimes.

You've made some insightful observations about your situation, and it's commendable that you're considering trying out small changes, like setting a goal for a gym session or coffee with a friend. Remember, these breaks are powerful tools that can enhance your productivity and well-being. It's normal to feel some guilt, but recognizing these breaks as essential is a significant step in the right direction. Let's focus on making these small changes and see how they impact you. You've got the strength to navigate this, and I'm here to support you as you find the balance that works for you.
Thanks, I appreciate it. I'll give it a shot and see how it goes. Hopefully, I can get better at managing the guilt over time.

concern:
Will be having my Master's Thesis proposal defense in the morning, and I'm all a bit tense and anxious and nervous and all the things that have going through my head. 

Been sleepy all day as if this is a way for me to cope with the stress it causes. Wish me luck everyone, good luck also to the countless graduate students who will be defending their own works!


Update: 

I cant believe it's done! I passed the proposal defence. Now I cant rest for a week from .

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm glad you're here today. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. I've been feeling so tense lately, especially with all these deadlines and presentations. It's just been a lot to handle.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed with everything on your plate right now. What do you think is contributing most to this tension?

client: Honestly, it's just the pressure of wanting to do well, you know? The thesis proposal was a big deal and I feel like there's always something next to tackle. It's exhausting mentally and physically.

That sounds really challenging, especially when you're striving to do your best. You feel exhausted because there's a continuous cycle of tasks and pressure. How do you usually cope with these feelings?

client: I try to take breaks and just zone out with some music or a good show, but it's hard to fully disconnect. Sometimes, it feels like even when I'm resting, my mind's still racing with all the things I need to do.
It seems like it's tough for you to find genuine rest when your mind is so active. When you think about potentially having more mental peace, what might be different in your life?
client: I guess I'd have more clarity and feel less like I'm constantly playing catch-up. Maybe I'd be more present in the moment and just enjoy things without that underlying anxiety.

Having more mental peace and clarity sounds really important to you. Based on what you've mentioned, possible options to support this could include setting specific times for breaks where you truly disconnect or exploring mindfulness practices. What are your thoughts on these options, or is there something else you'd like to consider?

Honestly, I think setting specific times for breaks could be helpful. I’ve heard good things about mindfulness, but I’m not sure where to start with it. Maybe just having a plan could make things feel a bit more manageable.

Creating a plan could definitely help make things feel more organized and manageable. How about we set a goal to start with scheduled breaks, and perhaps begin exploring mindfulness with small steps, like a short meditation or breathing exercise? We can also think about potential barriers and how you might overcome them. What do you think?

Yeah, I think that's a good idea. Starting with small steps sounds doable, especially with the scheduled breaks. I’m worried about staying consistent, though, so maybe having a strategy for when things get hectic would be good, too.

It's wonderful that you're open to starting with small steps. It's perfectly normal to have concerns about consistency, especially with such a busy schedule. Your idea of creating a strategy for hectic times is a great one, and shows you're really thinking ahead. Let's keep the focus on those scheduled breaks, and gently ease into mindfulness practices, like trying a short meditation or breathing exercise. 

Remember, it's okay to adjust and find what works best for you. You’re taking proactive steps towards creating a balance and that’s something to be proud of. As your next step, maybe set a reminder to pause for a break each day, and try out a brief meditation when you can. I'm here to support you as you navigate this journey. You're doing a fantastic job taking care of yourself, and together we'll work towards finding that mental peace and clarity you deserve.
Thanks, I appreciate your support. I'll give that a try and see how it goes, but I’m still a bit nervous about juggling everything.

concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Please feel free to share what's been on your mind or anything you'd like to talk about.
Hey, so I've been feeling kind of isolated in grad school lately. It's not that I don't have friends, but the challenges we face are just so specific, it sometimes feels like no one really gets it.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling isolated because the unique challenges of grad school make it hard for others to fully understand your experience. How has this been affecting you?
It's been a bit draining, honestly. I find myself feeling more stressed and less motivated because it feels like I'm going through all these challenges alone.
That sounds really tough, feeling drained and facing these challenges without support. What might life look like if you felt more connected and supported during grad school?

I think I'd feel more at ease, kind of like a weight's been lifted. Having people who understand would mean having someone to vent to or brainstorm with, and maybe it’d be more motivating to tackle everything.

Feeling more connected and supported sounds really important for you. Based on what you've shared, possible options to explore could include reaching out to a grad school group or joining an online community. How do these options resonate with you as potential steps to feeling more at ease?

Yeah, those sound like good ideas. I've actually started a GroupMe for grad students to connect, so I'm hoping that'll help me and others find some support and camaraderie. It's just nice to have a space where people get what you’re going through.

It's wonderful that you've taken the proactive step of starting a GroupMe for grad students. That shows your initiative and desire to create a supportive community. By fostering these connections, you're giving yourself and others the chance to feel understood and uplifted. Remember, it's okay to share your experiences and reach out for support when you need it. You're doing a great job. Keep nurturing these relationships, and over time, you'll find that sense of camaraderie you're looking for. Let's aim to check in on how this new group is helping and see if there are other ways to build connections as we move forward. You've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate your encouragement. I'll definitely try to keep these connections going and see how things progress.

concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm glad you're here today. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. I'm just feeling really stressed about my future, especially about finding a stable path to stay in the US.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling a lot of uncertainty and pressure about your future and securing stability. What about this situation is weighing most heavily on you right now?
client: I think it's the feeling that I don't have enough time to sort everything out. It's overwhelming trying to figure out grad school and job stability all at once.

It sounds like a lot is on your plate, and it’s understandable to feel overwhelmed with so much happening at once. What do you imagine your life might look like if you were to find that stability and clarity you're seeking?

I think it would feel like a huge weight lifted off my shoulders. I'd be more relaxed, knowing that I'm on a clear path and not constantly worried about having to leave the US or being stuck in limbo.
That sounds like a peaceful and fulfilling vision for your future. What are some small steps you think you might take towards achieving that clarity and stability?

client: Maybe starting by researching more grad programs that might accept my background or looking into possible job options that align with my skills. I could also talk to people in the field to get some advice.

It sounds like you have some clear ideas for moving forward, and those are great steps. Based on what you said, possible options include dedicating specific time each week to research grad programs and job options, and setting up informational interviews with professionals in your field. What do you think might be a good first step for you, and how can you anticipate and overcome any challenges you might face?

I think starting with research would be a good idea, just to get a clearer picture of what's out there. The challenge is staying motivated and not getting discouraged if I don't find options right away, so maybe setting small goals or timelines could help.

It's wonderful that you're considering starting with research, and setting small goals or timelines sounds like a practical strategy to maintain motivation. How about creating a plan where you dedicate a set amount of time each week to this research and define specific goals for what you hope to achieve within that period? What do you think could help you stay on track, and how might you monitor your progress?

I like the idea of dedicating a specific time each week to focus on research, and maybe using a planner or an app to keep track of my goals and progress. Checking in with myself weekly to see what I've accomplished could also help me stay on track and motivated.

You've put together a thoughtful plan to tackle these challenges one step at a time, and that's truly commendable. Dedicating time each week for research and using a planner or app to track your goals are effective strategies to stay organized and focused. Checking in with yourself weekly will help keep your motivation alive and provide a sense of accomplishment.

Remember, taking these small steps is progress in itself, and every little bit counts towards creating the future you envision. Stay compassionate with yourself through this journey. You're doing great work, and I'm confident you can navigate this path successfully. Until our next session, keep leaning on your strengths and celebrating each small victory.
Thanks, I appreciate it. I'll try to keep the momentum going and see how far I get. I'll let you know how it goes next time.

therapist: It sounds like you have some clear ideas for moving forward, and those are great steps. Based on what you said, possible options include dedicating specific time each week to research grad programs and job options, and setting up informational interviews with professionals in your field. What do you think might be a good first step for you, and how can you anticipate and overcome any challenges you might face?
client: I think starting with research would be a good idea, just to get a clearer picture of what's out there. The challenge is staying motivated and not getting discouraged if I don't find options right away, so maybe setting small goals or timelines could help.
therapist: It's wonderful that you're considering starting with research, and setting small goals or timelines sounds like a practical strategy to maintain motivation. How about creating a plan where you dedicate a set amount of time each week to this research and define specific goals for what you hope to achieve within that period? What do you think could help you stay on track, and how might you monitor your progress?
client: I like the idea of dedicating a specific time each week to focus on research, and maybe using a planner or an app to keep track of my goals and progress. Checking in with myself weekly to see what I've accomplished could also help me stay on track and motivated.
therapist: You've put together a thoughtful plan to tackle these challenges one step at a time, and that's truly commendable. Dedicating time each week for research and using a planner or app to track your goals are effective strategies to stay organized and focused. Checking in with yourself weekly will help keep your motivation alive and provide a sense of accomplishment.

Remember, taking these small steps is progress in itself, and every little bit counts towards creating the future you envision. Stay compassionate with yourself through this journey. You're doing great work, and I'm confident you can navigate this path successfully. Until our next session, keep leaning on your strengths and celebrating each small victory.
client: Thanks, I appreciate it. I'll try to keep the momentum going and see how far I get. I'll let you know how it goes next time.
